revision.comment: Typo/[[WP:AWB/GF|general]] fixes, replaced: manouvered (neither the US nor the UK spelling) → maneuvered (US spelling) using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name = F5L |image = File:Naval Air Station at Pensacola.jpg |caption = Curtiss F5L patrol plane at [[Pensacola Naval Air Station]] }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type = Military flying boat |manufacturer = [[Naval Aircraft Factory]] (137)
[[Curtiss Aircraft]] (60)
[[Canadian Aeroplanes Limited]] (30) |designer = [[John Cyril Porte]] |first flight = July 1918 |introduced = November 1918 |retired = 1928 |status = |primary user = [[United States Navy]] |more users = [[Aeromarine|Aeromarine Plane and Motor Company]] (Aeromarine 75) |produced = |number built = 227 |unit cost = |developed from = [[Felixstowe F.5]] |variants with their own articles = [[Naval Aircraft Factory PN]] }} |} The twin-engine '''F5L''' was one of the '''Felixstowe F''' series of [[flying boats]] developed by [[John Cyril Porte]] at the [[Seaplane Experimental Station]], [[Felixstowe]], England during the [[World War I|First World War]] for production in America. A civilian version of the aircraft was known as the '''Aeromarine 75'''. ==Design and development== Porte had taken the [[Curtiss H-12]], an original design by the American [[Glenn Curtiss]] and developed them into a practical series of flying boats at the Felixstowe station. They then took their [[Felixstowe F.5|F.5]] model and further redesigned it with better streamlining, a stronger hull using veneer instead of doped linen and U.S.-built 330 hp (later 400 hp) [[Liberty 12A]] engines. The prototype was built and tested in England and the design then taken over by the [[Naval Aircraft Factory]], Philadelphia, where further modifications were made to suit their production methods under wartime conditions.[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201022.html "USA Navy F-5-L Flying Boat."] ''[[Flight International|Flight]]'', 31 July 1919, pp. 1024–1026. The American-built version was also known as the '''Curtiss F5L''' and (in civilian operation) as the Aeromarine 75. The F5L was built by the Naval Aircraft Factory (137), [[Curtiss Aircraft|Curtiss]] (60) and [[Canadian Aeroplanes Limited]] (30). Some were converted for civilian use by the [[Aeromarine|Aeromarine Plane and Motor Company]] in 1919. ==Operational history== The F5L entered USN service at the end of the war and was the U.S. Navy’s standard patrol aircraft until 1928, when it was replaced by the [[Naval Aircraft Factory PN#Variants|PN-12]]. In civil service, named the '''Aeromarine 75''', the Felixstowe F5L could accommodate 10 passengers and was operated by [[Aeromarine Airways]] on flights from [[Key West]] to [[Havana]], carrying the first [[United States Postal Service|U.S. Post Office]] international [[air mail]] on flights from [[New York City]] to [[Atlantic City]], and from [[Cleveland]] to [[Detroit]]. ==Operators== [[File:F5L-flyingboats.jpg|thumb|right|Arrival at Guantanamo from Panama]] ;{{ARG}} *[[Argentine Naval Aviation]] ;{{BRA}} *[[Brazilian Naval Aviation]] - '''Curtiss F5L''' ;{{USA}} *[[United States Navy]] *[[Aeromarine Airways]] ==Accidents and incidents== [[File:Seaplane in flight.jpg|right|thumb|Aeromarine 75 ''Columbus'' on regular flights in the Caribbean]] On 13 January 1923, the Aeromarine Airways Aeromarine 75 ''Columbus'' suffered engine failure during a flight from Key West to Havana and landed in the [[Florida Strait]]. Buffeted by 10-to-15-foot (3-to-4.5-meter) waves, its hull began to fill with water. Four passengers died, but the ferry ship ''H. M. Flagler'' saved the other three passengers and both crew members.[http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19230113-0 Aviation Safety Network: Accident Description] ==Survivors== Both a hull and float from a US Navy F5L are preserved at the [[National Air and Space Museum]] ([[Smithsonian]]). The hull is only partially skinned with wood to reveal structure. Both artifacts are presently in storage and not available for public display.[http://www.nasm.si.edu/collections/artifact.cfm?id=A19240007015 "Float, Felixstowe F5L."] ''Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum'' (Smithsonian). Retrieved: 4 February 2011. ==Specifications== {{aircraft specifications| |plane or copter?=plane |jet or prop?=prop |ref=''Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum''[http://www.nasm.si.edu/research/aero/aircraft/felixstowe.htm "Felixstowe (NAF) F-5-L (hull only)."] ''Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum'' (Smithsonian). Retrieved: 4 February 2011. |crew=2 |capacity=12-14 passengers |length main= 49 ft 4 in |length alt=15.04 m |span main=103 ft 9 in |span alt=31.62 m |height main= 18 ft 9 in |height alt= 5.72 m |area main= 1,397 sq. ft |area alt= 129.8 m² |airfoil= |empty weight main= 8,720 lb |empty weight alt= 3,955 kg |loaded weight main= 14,334 lb |loaded weight alt= 6,508 kg |useful load main= |useful load alt= |max takeoff weight main= |max takeoff weight alt= |more general= |engine (prop)=[[Liberty L-12A]] |type of prop=V-12 water-cooled piston engines |number of props=2 |power main= 400 hp |power alt= kW |power original= |power more= |max speed main= |max speed alt= |max speed more= |cruise speed main= |cruise speed alt= 74 mph |cruise speed more= 120 km/h |never exceed speed main= |never exceed speed alt= |stall speed main= |stall speed alt= |stall speed more= |range main= 830 mi |range alt= 1335 km |range more= |ceiling main= |ceiling alt= |climb rate main= |climb rate alt= |loading main= |loading alt= |power/mass main= |power/mass alt= |more performance= |armament= * Two [[machine guns]] and bombs }} ==See also== {{aircontent |related= * [[Felixstowe F.2]] * [[Felixstowe F.5]] * [[Naval Aircraft Factory PN]] * [[Hall PH]] |similar aircraft= *[[English Electric Kingston]] *[[Supermarine Southampton]] |see also= |lists= }} ==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} * Bruce, J.M. "[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1955/1955%20-%201723.html The Felixstowe Flying-Boats: Historic Military Aircraft No. 11 Part 1".] ''[[Flight International|Flight]]'', 2 December 1955, pp. 842—846. * Bruce, J.M. "[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1955/1955%20-%201772.html The Felixstowe Flying-Boats: Historic Military Aircraft No. 11 Part 2".] ''Flight'', 16 December 1955, pp. 895–898. * Bruce, J.M. "[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1955/1955%20-%201806.html The Felixstowe Flying-Boats: Historic Military Aircraft No. 11 Part 3".] ''Flight'', 23 December 1955, pp. 929–932. * Donald, David and Jon Lake, eds. ''Encyclopedia of World Military Aircraft''. London: AIRtime Publishing, 1996. ISBN 1-880588-24-2. * Taylor, Michael J.H., ed. ''Jane's Encyclopedia of Aviation''. London: Studio Editions, Ltd., 1989. ISBN 0-517-10316-8. * Thetford, Owen. ''Aircraft of the Royal Air Force since 1918''. London: Putnam & Co., 1979. ISBN 0-370-30186-2. * [http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201022.html "U.S.A. Navy F-5-L Flying Boat (PDF) (Contemporary technical description with photographs and drawings; first part of two-part article)".] ''Flight'', XI (31), No. 553, 31 July 1919, pp. 1024–1026. Retrieved: 4 February 2011. * [http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201056.html "U.S.A. Navy F-5-L Flying Boat (PDF)(Second part of two-part article)."] ''Flight'', XI (32), No. 554, 7 August 1919, pp. 1058–1062. Retrieved: 4 February 2011. {{refend}} ==External links== {{commons category|Felixstowe F5L}} * [http://casmuseum.techno-science.ca/microsites/en/timeline/index.php?file=exhiblet_5&Lang=e&page=gallery Canadian Aeroplanes Ltd] Photographs including the first Felixstowe F5L built by the factory. * [http://vimyridgehistory.com/kit-3/home/war-industry/aircraft/#gallery/1169/2725 Canadian Aeroplanes Ltd]:Photographs including construction and assembly of the first F5L built by the factory from 30 April 1918. * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0Tp8faVtUu0 Film of US Navy F5Ls flying in formation] * [http://www.criticalpast.com/video/65675051032_USS-Ostfriesland_aircraft-parked_battleship-is-bombed_ship-submerges Film of US Navy F5Ls parked and sinking [[SMS Ostfriesland]], July 1921] * [http://www.criticalpast.com/video/65675070739_sea-plane_men-push-sea-plane_sea-shore_World-War-I Film of an F5L being maneuvered on a beaching trolley and other Curtiss types] * [http://www.timetableimages.com/ttimages/aerom.htm The Aeromarine Website] {{Seaplane Experimental Station aircraft}} {{Aeromarine}} [[Category:Felixstowe aircraft|F.5L]] [[Category:United States patrol aircraft 1910–1919]] [[Category:Flying boats]] [[Category:Curtiss aircraft]] [[Category:Naval Aircraft Factory aircraft]] [[Category:Twin-engined tractor aircraft]] [[Category:Biplanes]] [[Category:Aeromarine aircraft]]
